Package edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.ideal.common

Implementation classes for the ideal2 module.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    CommonIdealFactory
    An implementation of IdealFactory.
    IdealComparator
    Comparator for ideal numeric expressions.
    IdealSymbolicConstant
    A SymbolicConstant which is also a Primitive.
    MonicComparator
    A Comparator on Monics.
    NTConstant
    A constant which is not 1.
    NTMonic
    A non-trivial monic ("NTMonic") is the product of at least two PrimitivePowers.
    NTMonomial
    A non-trivial Monomial is the product of a Constant and a Monic.
    NTPolynomial
    An NTPolynomial ("non-trivial polynomial") is the sum of at least 2 Monomials with different underlying monics, e.g., 1+x 2, x+y, or x+xy.
    NTPrimitivePower
    A non-trivial primitive power represents a Primitive expression raised to some concrete integer exponent; the exponent is at least 2.
    NTRationalExpression
    A nontrivial RationalExpression.
    NumericPrimitive
    A numeric primitive expression---one which is to be considered as an atomic "variable" when used in other numeric expressions.
    One
    Empty monic: equivalent to 1.
    PrimitiveComparator
    A Comparator on Primitives, using the same order as that of IdealComparator.

Package edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.ideal.common Description

Implementation classes for the ideal2 module. There are classes with names beginning with "NT" (e.g., NTConstant). The "NT" stands for "non-trivial". See the documentation for each class for the interpretation of non-trivial, but in general the interpretation is that an element of that class cannot be represented an an element of a "simpler" class. For example, a non-trivial primitive power is a power of a primitive in which the exponent is at least 2, as such an element cannot be represented as a primitive. (In contrast, a primitive power with exponent 1 is equivalent to the primitive power.) The idea is to have a canonical representation of each element. Most of the arithmetic logic is contained in the class CommonIdealFactory. A number of additional utility classes are defined simply to help the factory (e.g., MonomialAdder, MonomialDivider, etc.).
